entries.text: Grammar is not about policing; it is about clarity. The goal is not perfection but being understood with minimal friction.
A sentence needs a subject and a verb. If you can’t find who is doing the action and what they are doing, you’re probably looking at a fragment.
“Its” with no apostrophe shows possession. “It’s” with an apostrophe always means “it is” or “it has.” If you can’t swap it with “it is,” remove the apostrophe.
Commas often mirror natural pauses, but not every pause deserves a comma. Use them for clarity, not decoration.
Active voice usually makes your writing cleaner and more powerful: “I broke the vase” is clearer than “The vase was broken by me.”
Subject–verb agreement is crucial. Strip the sentence down to the core noun when unsure: “The bouquet of roses is lovely”—the subject is bouquet, not roses.
Avoid comma splices: two sentences cannot be welded together with a comma alone. Use a period, semi-colon, or conjunction to join them correctly.
Adverbs often weaken writing when overused. If a sentence relies on 'really,' 'very,' or 'just,' rewrite it with stronger verbs and nouns instead.
Prepositions are relationship words: they show position, direction, or time. If a sentence feels clumsy, check if your prepositions are doing their job cleanly.
Avoid double negatives unless intentional for voice or dialect. In standard English, 'I don’t know anything' is cleaner than 'I don’t know nothing.'
A misplaced modifier attaches meaning to the wrong part of the sentence. 'Walking to the store, the rain soaked me' suggests the rain was walking. Place modifiers near what they describe.
Parallel structure makes writing flow. If you start a list with verbs, keep them all verbs; if you start with nouns, keep them all nouns. Consistency creates rhythm.
Not all run-on sentences are long; some are simply improperly joined. A run-on is two complete thoughts pretending to be one. Give each its own space or connect them properly.
Apostrophes show ownership or contraction, not pluralization. 'Three cat’s' is never correct unless those cats own something.
Colons introduce something: an explanation, a list, or a dramatic reveal. Think of them as a drumroll—what follows should complete or illuminate what came before.
Quotation marks go around direct speech or text someone actually said. Thoughts, feelings, and indirect speech do not need them unless stylistically chosen.
Hyphens connect closely linked words, like 'long-term' or 'high-quality.' When in doubt, ask if the two words create one meaning before the noun.
Ellipses (…) imply hesitation, omission, or trailing thought—not emotional collapse. Use them sparingly, or they dilute your message.
Semi-colons connect two complete, related sentences when a period feels too final. They are punctuation’s elegant bridge.
Your grammar does not define your intelligence or your worth. It is a tool—not a test. Use it to convey your truth, not to shrink your voice.
